# Solar Installation Training Program - Mosul ## Table 1 – Core Learning Objectives by Day | Day | Theme | Learning Objectives | |-----|-------|-------------------| | 1 | Solar Fundamentals & Load Analysis | • Identify solar opportunity in Iraq's energy crisis
• Calculate household loads in amperes (local context)
• Examine different panel types and quality indicators
• Use power meters for actual consumption measurement
• Understand basic site assessment principles | | 2 | System Components & Wiring | • Differentiate inverter types and internal components
• Master DC vs AC electrical principles and safety
• Select appropriate wire sizes and connectors
• Read and interpret component datasheets
• Practice proper MC4 connector installation | | 3 | Safety & System Integration | • Match panel strings to inverter specifications
• Configure series vs parallel connections safely
• Install proper DC protection devices
• Apply grounding and surge protection
• Troubleshoot common wiring errors | | 4 | Mounting Systems & Site Visits | • Calculate wind loads for Mosul conditions
• Install proper mounting structures
• Optimize panel angles for seasonal variation
• Conduct professional site assessments
• Document installation quality standards | | 5 | System Design & Business Skills | • Design complete PV systems using software
• Calculate ROI and payback periods
• Conduct market research (30 interviews)
• Develop maintenance schedules
• Master customer communication techniques | | 6 | Assessment & Job Connection | • Assemble complete system under time constraints
• Troubleshoot planted faults
• Present system design to mock employers
• Pass practical skills assessment
• Connect with solar company representatives | ## Table 2 – Daily Training Structure | Day | Morning (9:30-12:30)
Theory + Demonstration | Afternoon (1:30-3:30)
Hands-On Practice | Evening (3:30-4:00)
Review & Reflection | |-----|------------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------| | 1 | **Solar Opportunity & Components**
• Rising generator costs (5k→12k IQD)
• Panel types demonstration
• Load calculation in amperes
• Power meter introduction | **Home Energy Audit**
• Measure actual consumption
• Calculate daily usage patterns
• Introduction to measuring tools
• Google Earth site analysis | **Daily Review Circle**
• Each trainee shares key learning
• Anonymous sticky note feedback
• Preview next day topics | | 2 | **Inverter Technology & DC Safety**
• Open actual inverters
• DC electrical principles
• Datasheet interpretation
• Wire sizing calculations | **Wiring Workshop**
• Cut and prepare cables
• MC4 connector practice
• Battery system overview
• Common error demonstrations | **Group Discussion**
• Peer teaching moments
• Troubleshooting scenarios
• Safety protocol review | | 3 | **Component Compatibility**
• String voltage calculations
• Series/parallel configurations
• Protection device selection
• BMS programming basics | **4-Panel Installation**
• Wire panels correctly
• Test configurations
• Install protection devices
• Measure system outputs | **Problem-Solving**
• Groups present solutions
• Error identification game
• Technical Q&A session | | 4 | **Structural Design**
• Wind load calculations
• Mounting hardware types
• Shade analysis tools
• Professional assessment | **Site Visit**
• Live installation tour
• Quality inspection checklist
• Photo documentation
• Maintenance observation | **Field Experience Debrief**
• Site visit insights
• Installation challenges
• Customer interaction notes | | 5 | **System Design Software**
• Simulation tools overview
• Economic analysis
• Component selection
• Performance optimization | **Business Development**
• Market research practice
• ROI calculations
• Cleaning procedures
• Sales pitch development | **Design Presentations**
• Teams present designs
• Peer feedback session
• Instructor corrections | | 6 | **Assembly Competition**
• Timed system build
• Troubleshooting challenge
• Quality assessment
• Safety compliance check | **Mock Interviews**
• Company representatives
• Technical questions
• Portfolio review
• Job placement discussion | **Graduation Ceremony**
• Certificate presentation
• Industry networking
• Alumni group formation
• Next steps guidance | ## Table 3 – Participant Personas and Goals | Persona | Background | Challenge | Training Goal | Expected Outcome | |---------|------------|-----------|---------------|------------------| | **Recent Engineering Graduate** | Electrical/civil degree, no field experience | Theoretical knowledge but no practical skills | Master hands-on installation and troubleshooting | Entry-level position with solar installer | | **Displaced Technician** | Former factory electrician, needs new trade | Lost job due to conflict, supporting family | Quick employment in growing sector | Immediate hire as installation technician | | **Young Entrepreneur** | Small electrical shop owner | Customers asking for solar, lacks knowledge | Add solar installation to service offerings | Expand business with solar division | | **NGO Field Officer** | Community development background | Managing solar projects without technical knowledge | Understand systems for better project oversight | Effective solar project management | | **Women's Livelihood Participant** | Seeking economic opportunity | Cultural barriers to technical field entry | Gain skills for home-based solar business | Solar system sales and basic design | | **Former Generator Mechanic** | Diesel generator repair experience | Generator market declining | Transition skills to solar sector | Solar maintenance specialist role | ## Table 4 – Trainer Reference Guide | Trainer | Background | Key Insights | Signature Contribution | |---------|------------|--------------|----------------------| | **Hussam Falih** | RENAC-certified trainer, enterprise development specialist | "Dust accumulation is the top performance killer in Mosul" | Peer teaching methodology, 30-interview market research, after-sales focus | | **Saud Maan** | Electrical engineering professor, Dijla Engineering Office | "Iraqi learners retain best through practical work, not lectures" | Competition-based assessment, solar festival concept, SPD safety emphasis | | **Mohammed Al-Qatan** | 40MW installation experience, Mosul Solar Company director | "Never take notes - everything must be visual and hands-on" | No-notebook approach, mock job interviews, site visit integration | | **Ali Abkan** | Gisage technical support engineer, component specialist | "Fake warranties and counterfeit batteries flood the market" | Component comparison lab, warranty-adjusted ROI, troubleshooting scenarios | | **Muayad Hasan** | RENAC Master Trainer, 14 years in energy sector | "Engineers should start as technicians for 6 months first" | PVsyst simulation emphasis, anonymous feedback system, story-based teaching | ### Implementation Notes: - **Language**: All instruction in Arabic with English technical terms introduced gradually - **Group Size**: Maximum 20 participants, working in groups of 4-5 - **Equipment Ratio**: 1 inverter kit per 5 learners, 4 panels minimum for demonstrations - **Assessment**: 70% practical skills, 30% system design presentation - **Certification**: Co-branded with local solar companies and international recognition (RENAC pathway) - **Job Connection**: Day 6 employer panel, internship agreements with 10-15 local installers
